name: Naan
history: Naan is a popular leavened flatbread found in the cuisines of India and Central Asia. Traditionally cooked in a tandoor, this bread has become a beloved part of Indian cuisine, often served with curries and stews.
description: Naan is a soft and fluffy flatbread made from all-purpose flour, yeast, yogurt, and milk. It's known for its slightly chewy texture and the beautiful golden brown spots that form when cooked at high temperatures.

equipment.name: cast iron skillet or heavy pan

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. In a mixing bowl, combine all-purpose flour, salt, yeast mixture, yogurt, and milk. Knead into a soft dough. Cover and let it rise until doubled in size.

instructions.title: Roll and Cook Naan
instructions.description: Divide the dough into balls. Roll each ball into an oval shape. Heat a cast iron skillet or heavy pan. Cook each naan until it puffs up and brown spots appear, then flip and cook the other side. Brush with ghee or butter.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the naan warm with your choice of curry, dal, or other Indian dishes.

tips: The dough should be soft and pliable for the best texture.
Cooking on high heat is essential to achieve the characteristic bubbles and charred spots.
variations: Add minced garlic or chopped cilantro to the dough for a flavorful twist.
Experiment with stuffed naan fillings like cheese, potato, or spinach.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored in an airtight container for up to 1 day.
storage.instructions: Reheat on a skillet before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on a skillet or in a microwave until warm.

presentationTips: Serve on a platter with a side of mint chutney or yogurt.
Garnish with a sprinkle of fresh cilantro.
